translation.en: [reporter] This is a once-in-a-generation catastrophic tornado.
translation.ko: 일생에 보기 힘든 비극적인 토네이도가 발생했습니다

translation.en: [reporter] You've got to get, to your safe place… now.
[woman crying] We had a tornado. I'm so scared.
[child's voice] Is there anybody else out there?
[woman] All my co-workers are screaming,
"I'm gonna die. Tell my family I love them."
And I'm like, "We're not dying in here. We're not dying."
translation.ko: 저는 이렇게 대답했어요 ‘우린 절대 안 죽어’

translation.en: And then, boom! Everything just fell on us.
translation.ko: 그러다가 쾅 하고 모든 게 무너져 내렸어요

translation.en: Somebody please, send us some help. We are trapped.
translation.ko: 누가 구조대 좀 보내주세요 여기 사람이 갇혔어요

translation.en: Nobody can get to us.
I couldn't move and I started to panic.
translation.ko: 움직일 수 없었고 공황 상태에 빠졌죠

translation.en: I've watched all these movies about disasters and people getting trapped.
translation.ko: 재난이 일어나 사람이 갇히는 영화는 수도 없이 봤지만

translation.en: And I never would have thought that I would have lived,
through something like that.
[narrator] Every year, there are more than 1200 tornadoes in the United States.
translation.ko: 매년 1만 2천 개 이상의 토네이도가 미국에서 발생합니다

translation.en: Four times more than in the rest of the world combined.
translation.ko: 다른 국가의 토네이도를 전부 합친 것보다 4배 많습니다

translation.en: Each is simply a vortex of air.
But when that vortex is spinning at 200 miles an hour,
it becomes unstoppable.
-[first man] Oh, wow! -[second man] Wow!
[narrator] This is a film about people who chase tornadoes.
translation.ko: 이 영상에는 토네이도의 끔찍한 아름다움에 매혹되어

translation.en: Lured by their terrible beauty.
This whole place is just gone.
[narrator] And about the people whose lives are pulled apart,
by the destructive power of nature.
translation.ko: 삶이 갈가리 찢긴 사람들의 모습도 있습니다

translation.en: [narrator] Brandon Clement has been chasing tornadoes for over 20 years.
[Brandon] I had a tornado warning at the school I was going to
and they were trying to get us all in the hall and,
I may have just kind of skipped out and went to the parking lot,
got in my car and started chasing it. So…
It was probably a dumb move but, instantly I…
translation.ko: 멍청한 행동이긴 했지만 그 순간 바로 알게 됐어요

translation.en: it was like, "Okay, I like this."
[Brandon] By 2003, I was building chase vehicles,
and eventually started shooting video with it.
[narrator] Brandon is a professional chaser.
He makes a living posting footage of tornadoes online,
selling it to different media outlets.
translation.ko: 여러 매스컴에 팔아 수익을 만들고 있습니다

translation.en: [narrator] His chase partner is Brett Adair.
The chase is an adrenaline rush,
and anyone who says it's not, they would be lying.
translation.ko: 그렇지 않다고 말하는 사람은 거짓말하는 거죠

translation.en: This RFD is about to slam into us.
translation.ko: 후방 하강 기류가 우리와 충돌하기 직전이에요

translation.en: Right there's where the tornado would be though, right over the tree line.
[Brett] You don't know what to expect because every storm is different.
translation.ko: 예측할 수는 없어요 폭풍은 저마다 다르니까요

translation.en: Every system is different.
translation.ko: 폭풍은 각각 다른 체계를 갖고 있죠

translation.en: This RFD started just coming in.
We gotta go. We gotta go back north.
Let's go. Let's go. Let's go.
Then that adrenaline starts to kick in.
[Brett] Come on. Come on.
My passion is to be in violent weather.
translation.ko: 거친 날씨를 경험하고 싶은 열망이 있어요

translation.en: [Brett] Brandon and I,
we don't work together in a sense of being in the same vehicle.
translation.ko: 일하면서 이동할 때 같은 차을 타지 않아요

translation.en: There we go.
Wow.
[Brett] We may have a different opinion of where the best storm's gonna be.
translation.ko: 최고의 폭풍에 대해서는 서로 이견이 있을 수도 있어요

translation.en: So that's the storm. It's got lightning on it.
translation.ko: 저게 그 폭풍이에요 번개가 치고 있어요

translation.en: [Brett] And it's great, because you need somebody to push you.
Yeah, we have two spots.
Three spots now, if you look out to your two o'clock.
translation.ko: 이제 세 개가 됐어 2시 방향을 봐

translation.en: [Brett] So, it's kind of a competitive nature for the two of us too.
translation.ko: 우리 두 사람의 경쟁 본능이라고 할 수 있죠

translation.en: [man] Looks like a tornado on the ground.
I think it is.
[Brett] And that's how we operate.
[narrator] Each tornado, is spawned by a thunderstorm.
Warm, moist air rises.
It cools and condenses to form towers of cumulonimbus cloud.
But only one in 5000 thunderstorms has enough moisture,
translation.ko: 하지만 5천 개 중 하나만이 충분한 습기

translation.en: energy and wind speed to become a tornado.
Just forget the core of the storm. We need to stay just northeast of that.
translation.ko: 폭풍의 중심이 아니라 북동쪽에 있어야 해요

translation.en: Right?
Whatever's gonna take you northeast of the cloud base.
[Howard] I'm an observationist.
I like to go out in nature and observe these storms.
translation.ko: 자연으로 나가 이런 폭풍을 관찰하는 것을 좋아해요

translation.en: And then ask questions like, "Why are they there?
translation.ko: 그리고 질문하는 거예요 ‘왜 저곳에 있는 거지?’

translation.en: What causes them? What makes them look the way they do?"
translation.ko: ‘어떻게 발생한 거지? 저렇게 보이는 이유는 뭐지?’

translation.en: The ultimate goal is to look at a storm and say,
"This one is likely to produce a tornado, and this one is not."
[Howard] The source of the rotation of tornado is the horizontal row
translation.ko: 토네이도의 회전은 비가 내리고 증발하는 곳의 차가운 공기와

translation.en: that occurs along the boundary between the cool air,
translation.ko: 폭풍 외부의 따뜻하고 습한 일반적인 공기가

translation.en: where rain has fallen and evaporated,
and the regular warm moist air that's just outside the storm.
That's where the spin comes from.
That air which is spinning approaches the updraft,
the main buoyant updraft in the storm,
and it gets tilted up.
And lo and behold, you have a low level mesocyclone.
translation.ko: 그러면 신기하게도 낮은 수준의 메조 사이클론이 만들어지죠

translation.en: And this mesocyclone is a swirl of winds,
maybe, two, three, four kilometers across.
And as the air rises,
air has to come in from the sides to feed that updraft.
translation.ko: 상승 기류를 키우기 위해 측면에서 공기가 들어와야 해요

translation.en: And so that region of air which is spinning, contracts.
And so that stretches the column of air
and then you get a very intense vortex, right near the ground.
That's when you get the tornado.
This is just so spectacular, I can't even talk.
We dream of getting something like this.
Oh, man! Look at that.
I hope someone is getting that. Don't get me, get that.
translation.ko: 누가 좀 찍어주면 좋겠네요 나 말고 저걸 찍으세요

translation.en: [narrator] Spring is tornado season in the US…
when there's both warm and cool air in the atmosphere,
translation.ko: 대기에 따뜻한 공기와 차가운 공기가 동시에 있어서

translation.en: enough for a storm to start spinning.
It's also chasing season,
when there's the best chance of catching a twister in action.
[narrator] Brandon is chasing in Texas.
Heading Northwest towards Red River County.
translation.ko: 레드 리버 카운티를 향해 북쪽을 향하고 있습니다

translation.en: [Brandon] Right here is where the storms are starting to form.
translation.ko: 바로 이 지점에서 폭풍이 만들어지고 있어요

translation.en: You see the first storm blowing up.
And as they're coming towards you, you want to go towards them
and then you can get ready for Tornado Time.
Tornado Time is what I call, uh, in the afternoons, in the plains.
You know, that five o'clock to eight o'clock hour,
uh, that's where you get most of your tornadoes.
[narrator] Brett is also in Texas, driving south to Jasper.
translation.ko: 브렛도 텍사스에 있습니다 남쪽으로 재스퍼를 향하고 있죠

translation.en: Chasing down a different tornado.
translation.ko: 각자 다른 토네이도를 추적하고 있는 겁니다

translation.en: [Brett] We're going to stay on these until they start to show those MCS signs
translation.ko: 중규모 대류계 신호가 보일 때까지 있을 거야

translation.en: and then we're going to blow East.
It's good to know that they're coming across.
I see your area over there is now
under a severe thunderstorm watch for the afternoon.
[Brandon] Yeah. They have put a tornado watch out for us.
translation.ko: 응, 우리 때문에 토네이도 경계선도 만들었어

translation.en: It's the last circle on the drylines.
All right. Cool. Hey, do you know anything that's good to eat down near DeRidder?
translation.ko: 좋아, 혹시 데리더에 맛집 아는 곳 있어?

translation.en: Of course, he would lose signal.
Brandon, I'm getting hangry. Answer me, boy.
Here it goes.
You definitely see it trying now.
translation.ko: 어떻게 만들어지는지 확실히 볼 수 있어요

translation.en: See how the width of the clouds in the front are going up?
translation.ko: 바로 앞의 구름 폭이 올라가는 게 보이죠?

translation.en: The back side is coming back around.
That's exactly what you want to see.
Hopefully it can continue to develop and then we'll get a nice,
translation.ko: 계속 저렇게 발달해서 바로 앞에서 멋진 토네이도를

translation.en: tight tornado right in front of us.
Like we were talking about earlier, Tornado Time.
You know, we're just now getting into that window.
So I think this storm finally may put one down.
translation.ko: 제가 보기엔 이 폭풍이 토네이도가 될 것 같아요

translation.en: Oh, yeah.
Full tornado on the ground.
I'm getting out right here.
[Brandon] Most tornadoes only last a few minutes.
translation.ko: 대부분의 토네이도는 단 몇 분만 지속돼요

translation.en: Sometimes just seconds.
Oftentimes, our footage is the only evidence that they ever existed.
translation.ko: 우리 영상이 토네이도의 유일한 증거가 될 때도 있어요

translation.en: We're like journalists, documenting each storm.
Bearing witness to the destruction it causes.
Is anybody in the car?
[Brandon] Chasers like me,
we're here when the destruction is happening.
So it's before the First Responders even get here.
Watch the power lines.
[Brandon] It's our moral obligation to find out if anyone is hurt
translation.ko: 다친 사람을 찾고 최선을 다해 돕는 건

translation.en: and do what we can to help.
[Brandon] Y'all okay?
Yeah, they were in the shelter.
Good place to be.
Yeah. Scary, man.
Is it just you?
-Huh? -Just you?
-Right. -Nobody else inside or anything?
-No. -Good.
Can you turn that main switch on the propane tank off?
Yeah, we can.
Yeah.
-I cut it back on. -Watch out.
Pretty good.
Yeah. All right, come on. They're all right.
Good thing they were in the shelter.
You can still see the tornado. Quite a rope.
Okay.
[Brandon] It always amazes me,
how something so beautiful can do so much damage.
I'm over here near Jasper with this one that's coming, uh, out of Woodville.
translation.ko: 재스퍼에서 다가오는 토네이도를 보고 있어, 우드빌 외곽이야

translation.en: [narrator] Meanwhile, Brett is 200 miles further south,
trying to locate a different storm.
This has got some wind. It's…
you can see the inflow but man, it's super cool.
translation.ko: 공기가 유입되는 게 보일 거야 정말 굉장해

translation.en: I can go just south of town right here at Jasper, that's what I'm,
I'm trying to make a decision here though pretty quick.
Maybe we should go a little south, get in a better position.
translation.ko: 좋은 위치를 잡으려면 약간 남쪽으로 가야 할 거야

translation.en: All right man, we'll talk. Bye.
Uh-oh. Right here.
I hate this, man.
[narrator] By the time he hones in on a tornado,
it's so wrapped in rain, he can't see anything.
[man] Copy that.
There it is. Look out your window, right there.
That's a tornado over there to the left.
[Brett] When you get in those situations in the rain,
it's like a big washing machine.
translation.ko: 마치 큰 세차 기계 안에 있는 것 같아요

translation.en: Buckle up and get ready for the ride.
[narrator] Most tornadoes in the US,
happen on the Great Plains in Tornado Alley.
It's wedging out, and you're probably seeing a sheer,
a sheer zone,
with it going up and over.
[narrator] The geography is perfect, for the formation of big storms.
translation.ko: 이곳은 큰 폭풍 형성에 완벽한 지형을 갖고 있습니다

translation.en: [Howard] When the air comes in from the Pacific over the Rocky Mountains,
it subsides.
And as that air subsides,
pressure increases, and that pressure squeezes the air
and it warms it up.
As it warms up,
you get southerly winds ahead of it.
And those southerly winds bring up moisture
from the Gulf of Mexico to fuel the storms that form.
So, it's very important to be here,
because we have the mountains and we have the Gulf of Mexico.
[man] Howie, we should go.
Uh, we need to go.
[narrator] Tornado Alley, has more violent tornadoes than anywhere on Earth.
translation.ko: 토네이도 앨리는 가장 위협적인 토네이도가 발생하는 곳입니다

translation.en: [narrator] Each is measured on the EF-Scale.
Based on wind speed and structural damage.
[narrator] Only one percent of tornadoes in the US
are EF4s or EF5s,
classified as violent tornadoes.
[man whimpers] Until you see this in person, you have no idea.
It's… it's devastation.
[narrator] On average, there's fewer than one EF5 per year,
translation.ko: 평균적으로 EF5 토네이도는 연간 1회 미만으로 발생합니다

translation.en: but they're the storms that live on in the memory.
translation.ko: 하지만 한 번 발생하면 영원히 잊을 수 없습니다

translation.en: [man] Look at the size of that monster.
[man] Jesus!
[narrator] The El Reno Tornado still haunts those who were there.
translation.ko: 엘 리노의 토네이도는 여전히 주민들에게 큰 상처입니다

translation.en: All right. We are near El Reno, Oklahoma.
We have a rapidly rotating wall cloud just to our west.
Once that first lightning strike happens,
I'm instantly wondering, how long until I see a tornado.
[Brandon] Wow, this thing just keeps forming new vortices.
In that moment, I see one little funnel and it touches the ground.
translation.ko: 그 순간 작은 회오리가 땅에서 솟아오르고

translation.en: And then I see another little funnel and it touches the ground.
translation.ko: 또 하나의 작은 회오리가 솟아오르는 게 보여요

translation.en: But what I don't realize is that the whole sky
is actually about to become a tornado.
[woman] Because we knew there was a lot of potential
for strong tornadoes on this day,
and we knew there were so many storm chasers everywhere,
we decided to give the storm a lot of space.
So, when we went to our first position watching the El Reno storm,
translation.ko: 엘 리노 폭풍을 관찰한 최초 지점은

translation.en: we were about six miles away from it.
You're kind of hoping that the rear flank downdraft is going to clear out
translation.ko: 최고의 상황은 후방 하강 기류가 없어지고

translation.en: and you're going to get a beautiful shot of the tornado that's under there.
translation.ko: 저기 있는 토네이도를 아름답게 담아내는 거예요

translation.en: [Brandon] We were there chasing. I actually had my dad with me.
And when the tornado formed, it was several miles off to our west.
translation.ko: 토네이도가 만들어진 지점은 서쪽으로 단 몇 킬로미터였고

translation.en: Had a good viewing position.
Very relaxed environment.
And the tornado started growing…
from when we first got in the car, as a small,
few hundred yard wide multi-vortex,
translation.ko: 수백 미터 정도 직경의 여러 회오리가

translation.en: to at this point, a two and a half to three-mile-wide just monster.
Looking right at it.
[Brandon] We got 30 seconds. Turn the car around!
[Brandon] I wanted the car turned around
so that we wasted no time in getting out of there.
But all I wanted to do in that moment was,
translation.ko: 하지만 그 순간 제가 진짜 원했던 건

translation.en: was film it,
because I'd never seen anything like it before.
The fact that it was so mesmerizing kept me in that moment
for too long.
[narrator] There were 250 chasers on the scene that day,
their locations mapped by GPS.
They weren't prepared for the speed of the oncoming storm.
translation.ko: 추적자들은 다가오는 폭풍의 속도에 대비하지 못했습니다

translation.en: [Jennifer] We were only 90 seconds away from that tornado hitting our location.
[man] Jump in!
[Jennifer] We've got to haul ass.
[Jennifer] We got in our vehicle
and we pulled out and screamed east as fast as we could.
translation.ko: 비명을 지르면서 최대한 빠르게 동쪽으로 달렸죠

translation.en: [Jennifer] Go. Go. Go. Go!
-[Jennifer] Drive! Fuck. -[man] Let's go.
[Jennifer] Fuckin' shit.
Imagine being chased by something that's two and a half miles wide,
moving at 55 miles per hour.
[Jennifer] And it was actually gaining on us.
All you can hope is that the road you're on continues for miles and miles,
translation.ko: 길이 무사히 이어져 있기를 바랄 뿐이었죠

translation.en: so you can continue to drive away as fast as you can.
translation.ko: 그래야 최대한 빨리 차를 몰아 달릴 수 있으니까요

translation.en: [Brandon] We had to turn around back across the tornado.
At this point, I'm having trouble keeping the vehicle on the road.
translation.ko: 도로에서 차를 계속 몰기 힘든 상황이었죠

translation.en: And I knew we're about to take a direct hit.
translation.ko: 토네이도가 우리를 치기 직전이란 걸 알았어요

translation.en: And there was nothing I could do about it.
translation.ko: 제가 할 수 있는 건 없었어요

translation.en: All I could think, is just keep the nose of the car in the wind.
translation.ko: 바람 속에서 차를 계속 몰아야 한다는 생각뿐이었죠

translation.en: I knew if we got sideswiped in any way that car was going rolling
translation.ko: 차의 측면이 강타당하면 그대로 차가 전복되고

translation.en: and we weren't gonna make it.
[Brandon] I realized this tornado was going towards my escape route.
translation.ko: 토네이도가 제 탈출 경로로 다가오고 있다는 걸 깨달았어요

translation.en: Whoa! Go! I'll get the tripod. Just drive! Just drive!
translation.ko: 가, 삼각대는 내가 챙길게 빨리 출발해!

translation.en: [Brandon] And that's when we decided to go south as fast as we could.
translation.ko: 그 순간 최대한 빨리 남쪽으로 달리기로 했어요

translation.en: Go! Winds!
[Brandon] And we started having headwinds that were probably over 100-mile-an-hour.
And the car could just not go any faster.
Forty is not enough!
I can't see.
You're fine. You're good. I can see for you. Go!
translation.ko: 괜찮아, 잘하고 있어 내가 봐줄게, 속도 올려

translation.en: Go!
[Brandon] I yell at my driver to drive south.
translation.ko: 운전하는 친구에게 남쪽으로 가라고 소리 질렀죠

translation.en: Just go! Don't stop now! Go!
translation.ko: 계속 가, 멈추면 안 돼! 빨리 가!

translation.en: Because if he stops, if we hesitate
any more than we already did by me taking too much time…
translation.ko: 이미 저 때문에 많이 지체된 상황이라

translation.en: we're not gonna make it.
Go south! If you don't go south, we're gonna die!
translation.ko: 남쪽으로 가야 해! 안 그러면 우린 죽어!

translation.en: -It's okay? -Yes, just drive south!
translation.ko: - 지금 괜찮은 거야? - 응, 그냥 남쪽으로 가!

translation.en: [Brandon] There was farm equipment coming right at my vehicle.
Shit.
[Brandon] It shattered my windshield immediately.
Get down! Duck down! Duck down!
Drive forward if you can.
[Brandon] So we slam into this 2000-pound hay bale.
[Brandon] You're good.
Oh, shit!
[Brandon] And it just adds to the chaos of the moment.
[driver] I can't see.
Okay, that's fine.
[Brandon] We realized then that the worst has passed us
and that the tornado had curved back off to the northeast
and we had just escaped out of the south.
Oh, my God!
Yeah, my car is totaled.
Just drive.
[Brandon] I've seen so many tornadoes.
And I've seen the damage that they cause.
But actually being in that situation and thinking you might not make it out
translation.ko: 실제로 그런 상황에 처하고 희망이 사라지자

translation.en: just totally reframes the perspective,
uh, and the respect for Mother Nature.
[Jennifer] When we finally felt we were in a safe enough position to stop,
we got out.
And when we looked up at the storm,
we can see the entire mesocyclone.
It was totally and utterly awe-inspiring.
And for a moment you forgot the horrible beast that was underneath it.
translation.ko: 그 속에 어떤 괴물이 있는지 완전히 잊게 되는 순간이었어요

translation.en: I said out loud, "Wow, I hope all the storm chasers are safe."
And, uh, that ended up being about six minutes after
translation.ko: 그리고 6분 뒤 그 말은 희망으로 끝나버렸죠

translation.en: Tim Samaras, Paul Samaras, and Carl Young had actually been hit by that tornado.
translation.ko: 팀 사마라스, 폴 사마라스 칼 영이 토네이도에 휩쓸렸어요

translation.en: [Jennifer] They were the first storm chasers ever killed by a tornado.
translation.ko: 토네이도로 인해 사망한 최초의 추적자들이 되었고요

translation.en: I can only imagine, that it was very hard to see.
translation.ko: 앞을 보기 힘들었을 거라고만 짐작할 뿐이에요

translation.en: It probably moved very fast
and they probably didn't realize
the danger that they were in until it was too late.
[narrator] The season is over in Tornado Alley.
There have been no violent tornadoes.
When that, that storm complex dives…
[narrator] Brett Adair and Brandon Clement are back on home territory in the South.
You know, you're in Mississippi, you live here, I live in Alabama.
translation.ko: 넌 여기 미시시피에 살고 난 앨라배마에 살아

translation.en: For me, personally, I might stay a little east tonight.
If we get those type of parameters along I-20, Birmingham--
translation.ko: 이런 요소가 버밍엄 I-20 도로를 따라 발생하면

translation.en: Yeah, the symbol is right there.
Right.
[narrator] Alongside Tornado Alley, is Dixie Alley.
translation.ko: 토네이도 앨리 옆에는 딕시 앨리가 있습니다

translation.en: Cutting through the southern states of Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama.
It has more violent tornadoes per square mile than its larger neighbor.
translation.ko: 토네이도 앨리보다 더 위협적인 폭풍이 발생해

translation.en: And those tornadoes continue later in the year.
With a second spike in the fall.
translation.ko: 가을은 토네이도가 두 번째로 많이 발생하는 계절입니다

translation.en: [Brandon] Chasing in the South, to me, is different than the Plains.
I have kids, I have a mother, I have friends.
translation.ko: 전 아이도 있고 어머니도 친구도 있어요

translation.en: And it's terrifying knowing that
these tornadoes that I'm out here chasing could, you know,
translation.ko: 곧 그 사람들을 덮칠 거란 사실을 깨달으면

translation.en: be going at them next.
-[Brandon] Hi. -[woman] Hey.
[Brandon] Be ready, 'cause they're a lot worse
than what the radar is representing all day long.
translation.ko: 보여주는 것보다 훨씬 더 강력할 테니까

translation.en: So be careful.
It's coming right towards the house.
[woman] Yes.
[Brandon] I, uh, if you can hear me, I love you. Gotta go.
translation.ko: 할 말이 있어 사랑해, 이제 끊어야 해

translation.en: -[woman] I love you too. Bye. -Bye.
[narrator] Tornadoes in fall are normally weaker than those in spring.
Blowing out by Thanksgiving.
But not this year.
-Oh, shit. -Wow!
[narrator] The Gulf of Mexico is warmer than it's been in December for 40 years.
translation.ko: 지난 40년 이래 멕시코만의 12월 수온은 최고가 됐습니다

translation.en: Increasing evaporation adding moisture into the atmosphere.
translation.ko: 증발하는 양이 늘어나면 대기에 습기가 더해집니다

translation.en: As warm, moist air heads inland,
it collides with cold air further north
and strong winds in the upper atmosphere…
a recipe for the worst winter tornado in Kentucky's history.
translation.ko: 이렇게 켄터키 역사상 최악의 겨울 토네이도가 만들어졌습니다

translation.en: This is the most remarkable,
destructive tornado that I have seen around here.
[Trent] As this storm moved over our area,
we were able to detect winds of well over 150 miles per hour.
translation.ko: 풍속 240km/h 이상의 바람을 감지할 수 있었습니다

translation.en: And that's incredible.
This was a storm, you know, on radar,
you might see out in Oklahoma or Texas, but not here.
translation.ko: 오클라호마나 텍사스에서 주로 볼 수 있는 태풍이죠

translation.en: You know, in 14 years of working at the station,
I've never seen anything this powerful.
That night, we had to take our message up to the highest level of urgency.
translation.ko: 그날 밤 최고 수준의 경보를 계속 발령해야 했어요

translation.en: We may be looking at a one-mile-wide tornado.
Just incredible, incredible winds.
This is a once-in-a-generation catastrophic tornado
translation.ko: 역사에 길이 남을 일생에 보기 힘든

translation.en: that will be talked about for years.
We were telling people to get mattresses,
pull those off your beds.
Take those into your, your safe room with you.
Get baseball helmets, football helmets.
Put those on your head.
Make sure that you've got, uh, pull out some pillows…
[Trent] This was the type of storm that if you weren't in a basement,
you were in danger.
And so we had to try to tell people, you know, uh,
to take every precaution necessary to try to save their lives.
I cannot, cannot tell you with any greater urgency.
translation.ko: 지금 정말 위험하다는 경고를 드리는 겁니다

translation.en: You've got to get to your safe place now!
When I heard the thunder, I came over to this door.
translation.ko: 이 문으로 들어올 때 천둥소리가 들렸어요

translation.en: And then I turned around.
And when I looked again,
I saw a big flash of white light.
I looked outside
and all of a sudden, debris started whipping up
and the door started shaking.
So I went ahead and locked the door.
I said, "Everybody, let's go to the bathroom."
So we started walking all the way over here.
Came into the restroom, and we all huddled in here.
We were scared, it was terrifying.
Just the sound and the debris hitting the house.
translation.ko: 바람과 물건이 집에 부딪히는 소리만 들렸어요

translation.en: I mean, I can hear tree trunks just hitting and slamming.
translation.ko: 나무 밑동이 날아와서 부딪히는 소리를 들었다니까요

translation.en: And the windows breaking from that side,
and, the way it just came.
It felt like it was coming this way, just like this.
So it's, it's a terrible feeling.
It's, not a wonderful feeling.
And right now I'm hearing it like if it was that day.
Just talking about it makes me feel that it's happening right now.
translation.ko: 이렇게 얘기하다 보면 그때 느낌이 그대로 살아나요

translation.en: [narrator] As a Southerner, Brett was the only professional storm chaser
in a position to capture the tornado on camera.
[Brett] This storm dropped tornadoes all the way from Arkansas to Northeast Kentucky.
translation.ko: 아칸소와 켄터키 북동쪽 전체에 토네이도가 발생했어요

translation.en: I mean, that's literally like the storm chaser's lottery.
translation.ko: 폭풍 추적자에게는 말 그대로 로또가 당첨된 거죠

translation.en: And when it lights up and you're like, "Holy smokes!"
[Brett] You can see the debris being lofted and thrown,
and that's what we were watching for
when Mayfield was hit.
And unfortunately, it was hit, and hit hard.
[narrator] The full wrath of the storm was focused on the city of Mayfield,
translation.ko: 폭풍의 분노 전체가 켄터키주 서부 메이필드에

translation.en: in Western Kentucky.
[Brett] So we roll up
and everything's trashed all around you.
You know, people yelling, the candle factory's been destroyed.
translation.ko: 사람들이 양초 공장이 무너졌다고 소리를 질렀어요

translation.en: There was so much debris.
You know, it took first responders and took us a moment to get through that.
translation.ko: 응급 구조대와 우리가 지나가는 데 한참이 걸렸어요

translation.en: And it looked like an unworldly, ungodly situation
translation.ko: 이 세상이 아니라 마치 지옥 같았어요

translation.en: that you can only imagine that you see in movies.
[Brett] This is a factory that employs well over 100 people.
And seeing that, just the entire building structure, just gone.
translation.ko: 그 사람들의 일터가 통째로 무너져 내렸죠

translation.en: Honestly, I thought, "There's no way anybody survived this."
translation.ko: 이런 생각이 들었어요 ‘살아남은 사람은 없을 거야’

translation.en: [woman] We're at the candle factory in Mayfield,
and we are trapped.
Please, y'all, get us some help.
Please. Please.
[woman] I went on Facebook Live because
for one, I needed to keep talking.
I needed to ramble
so that I wouldn't be focused on what was going on.
But also because I needed somebody to know that we were stuck.
I don't know who's watching.
We had a tornado and the building fell.
I'm so scared.
Is anybody out there?
All my coworkers are screaming,
"I'm gonna die. Tell my family I love them."
And I'm like, "We're not dying in here. We're not dying."
translation.ko: 저는 이렇게 대답했어요 ‘우린 절대 안 죽어’

translation.en: And I'm like, "It's almost my birthday."
And so, you know, a lot of that was on the Live.
It's almost ten o'clock. Y'all gonna sing "Happy Birthday" to me.
translation.ko: 다들 곧 나한테 생일 축하 노래 불러줄 거예요

translation.en: [overlapping voices] ♪ Happy birthday to you ♪
We're gonna sing now. Y'all gotta sing "Happy Birthday" to me.
translation.ko: 얼마 안 남았어요 다들 노래 불러주게 될 거예요

translation.en: [overlapping voices] ♪ Happy birthday to you ♪
Okay. Okay, y'all.
I wanna get out.
[Brett] We pulled three or four people out the whole time I was there,
which was around four hours.
But you know there were people underneath the pile that didn't make it.
translation.ko: 구할 수 없는 사람이 있다는 걸 알고 있었어요

translation.en: All you can do is…
is comfort the ones that could hear you and say,
"Just hold on. Just hold on.
Uh, we're coming. We're trying. We're on the way."
And…
it was just rough. It was really rough.
[man] Help!
I hope that's people that, like, know what the fuck they doing.
translation.ko: 사람들이 뭘 제대로 알고 하는 거면 좋겠네요

translation.en: -Y'all. -No, you loose?
[Kyanna] Andrea got loose first and they pulled her out.
Then Dakota, then Daniela.
But I was so afraid that they wasn't gonna be able to get me out.
translation.ko: 절 꺼내주지 못할까 봐 너무 무서웠어요

translation.en: I said, "I got a big ass."
And I'm like, "I'm not going to fit." And they got underneath me.
translation.ko: ‘살 뺄 생각이 없었는데 그래서 이렇게 깔렸나 봐요’

translation.en: See, this is a State Trooper.
Got my butt and pushed it up,
and Gary was at the top and he was pulling.
Hey y'all, they got me out.
[Kyanna] And I got up to the top and I got out.
I'm out.
[Kyanna] Seeing the factory now, it is unbelievable.
I mean, you would have thought that one of the Three Little Pigs made it.
Like the one that made it of straw.
[narrator] The next morning, Brandon got the first drone footage,
translation.ko: 다음 날 아침, 브랜던은 드론 촬영을 시작했습니다

translation.en: of the damage at Mayfield.
Wow, it's,
this whole place is just gone.
[Brandon] I mean, I just love seeing the power of Mother Nature,
until you see this.
It looks like somebody hooked up a giant tiller
translation.ko: 마치 누군가가 거대한 경운기를 몰고 와서

translation.en: and just came for a mile-wide, right through this area.
Slab right there. Slab right there.
-Right. -Slab right there.
Right.
[Brandon] It's almost like a CSI case, trying to unravel a murder, you know.
translation.ko: 마치 살인을 해결하는 CSI 사건 같아요

translation.en: Right there is where, debris rowing and stuff.
-Yeah. -You see all that debris going out.
I mean, that's just as intense as it gets right there.
Yup.
There's a small little sector.
[Brandon] I've been hit by big tornadoes before but, at least I had a chance.
translation.ko: 저도 토네이도를 겪었지만 저에게는 기회가 있었어요

translation.en: These people didn't have a chance.
[Peter] We've seen storms. We've been through storms.
translation.ko: 우린 폭풍을 봤어요 폭풍을 직접 겪었죠

translation.en: But nothing like this.
Nothing like this.
This is more than just a house.
It's where I raised my children.
My son said,
"Man,
I played on this property, I played all around in here."
And, uh, he had never expressed his nostalgic views of, the home…
translation.ko: 이전에는 집에 대한 향수를 표현한 적이

translation.en: until this, you know?
I'm not giving this up. I'm fighting for it.
[reporter] Breeanna Glisson still hasn't figured out
translation.ko: 브리아나 글리슨은 아직도 이해할 수 없습니다

translation.en: how she and her four and two-year-old children are alive.
[Breeanna] There was warnings going off like crazy and sirens going off.
But I had nowhere safe to go.
So I grabbed my kids
and I laid down in my bed, my mattress.
Held onto them.
Um, the windows shattered.
Any and all glass was gone.
And that's when I saw the roof coming at me.
translation.ko: 그때 갑자기 지붕이 날아오는 게 보였어요

translation.en: It felt like one solid motion.
translation.ko: 순간 정지된 것 같은 느낌이 들었어요

translation.en: It crushed us and then we were flown,
and so was the whole house.
In a millisecond,
we were no longer in the bed or in our house.
translation.ko: 몸을 숨겼던 침대와 집이 사라져 버렸어요

translation.en: We were on the ground all the way over there somewhere.
translation.ko: 어딘지도 모를 곳에서 토네이도에 노출되어 있었죠

translation.en: Like on the other side of those cars?
Like over this rubble, on the ground, in mud.
[Breeanna] We were stuck there for hours and hours.
And it took so long for someone to come and help
because there was-- nobody could get in.
There was so much damage and debris over the roads.
translation.ko: 부서진 건물과 잔해로 길이 다 막혀 있었어요

translation.en: They couldn't get to us.
That tornado was huge.
I don't understand how I'm even alive after going through it.
translation.ko: 그런 일을 겪고 어떻게 살아남았는지 모르겠어요

translation.en: Every time I close my eyes, I see the roof, crushing us.
translation.ko: 눈을 감을 때마다 우리를 덮친 지붕이 떠올라요

translation.en: I wouldn't wish my worst enemy to go
through something like what I've been through.
translation.ko: 이런 일은 절대 겪지 않았으면 좋겠어요

translation.en: [narrator] The tornado outbreak killed at least 88 people.
It caused four billion dollars worth of damage.
[Brandon] We've had more billion-dollar disasters over the past ten years
translation.ko: 지난 10년 동안 일어난 10억 달러 규모 재난이

translation.en: than we have in decades prior to that.
translation.ko: 수십 년간 일어난 재난보다 더 많죠

translation.en: These types of events, are just going to happen more frequently
translation.ko: 이런 사건은 앞으로 더 자주 일어날 거예요

translation.en: as we see a warmer climate develop.
We just have to be prepared for more extreme events to occur.
translation.ko: 더 위험한 사고가 발생할 걸 대비해야 해요

translation.en: [Breeanna] We usually don't have tornadoes in Kentucky.
Seriously, like, it is not a normal thing.
And with the way that the planet is changing,
I feel like it's going to get worse.
translation.ko: 점점 더 나빠질 거라는 느낌이 들어요

translation.en: [narrator] In recent years, as the planet warms,
translation.ko: 최근 수년 동안 지구의 온도가 올라가면서

translation.en: the boundaries of Tornado Alley and Dixie Alley
have been shifting further north and east
into more heavily populated parts of the country.
translation.ko: 인구가 더 많은 지역으로 확장한 겁니다

translation.en: Areas without storm shelters.
translation.ko: 폭풍을 피할 시설이 전혀 갖춰지지 않은 곳이죠

translation.en: [Brandon] There's definitely some causation with climate change.
Because you're getting these strong systems that come in
translation.ko: 점점 더 강력한 시스템이 도입되고 있어요

translation.en: that normally don't have enough energy, enough juice to produce,
translation.ko: 더 많은 에너지를 소모하고 더 많이 생산하고 있어요

translation.en: you know, the big tornadoes.
And now they do, and this is the result.
It's just,
I mean, you know,
if we don't start doing something about climate change,
translation.ko: 기후 변화를 위해 아무것도 하지 않으면

translation.en: it's just gonna continue to get worse.
[narrator] A month after the tornado, the demolition crews move in.
translation.ko: 토네이도가 발생하고 한 달 뒤 철거 인력이 도입되고

translation.en: The clean up operation begins.
[woman] Every disaster you go to is different,
but the personal impact is the same.
People are grieving, people are hurting.
People don't want to walk out their door every day
and see the disaster and piles like this.
They just want an ounce of hope and an ounce of recovery.
translation.ko: 그들에게 필요한 건 약간의 희망과 복구뿐입니다

translation.en: And if we can bring that, then that's our goal.
That's what keeps us coming back.
The mindset is, you know, this is my home.
This is where I grew up.
This is where my family is and so, you're gonna rebuild.
[narrator] A symbol of the disaster was a photograph,
translation.ko: 재난은 무너진 영화관의 잔해 속에서 찍은 사진으로

translation.en: taken in the rubble of a movie theater.
So I posted the photo and everybody liked it.
And uh, I didn't realize how quickly it would catch on,
but I think now it's got close to like 160,000 upvotes.
translation.ko: 지금은 업로드 수가 16만 회쯤 될 거예요

translation.en: You know, as of now, we've raised over 70,000 dollars on GoFundMe.
I had a guy just hand me a big wad of cash one day.
translation.ko: 어느 날 한 남자가 저에게 큰 돈다발을 건넸어요

translation.en: And he said, "I heard what you were doing. I saw it on CNN.
Like, I just want to help you out as best I could. Here you go."
And I think that really says a lot about this community.
translation.ko: 그 일은 이곳에서 의미하는 바가 크다고 생각해요

translation.en: [man] When this thing first started, a lot of people couldn't get a hot meal.
translation.ko: 처음에는 많은 사람이 따뜻한 음식을 먹지도 못했어요

translation.en: Of course, by me being a cook,
I've been trying to help people as much as I can.
We're all in this together.
And we need to stick together to help one another to rebuild it.
translation.ko: 재건을 위해 함께 뭉쳐서 서로를 도와야 해요

translation.en: Okay, you want to take those and then come back?
translation.ko: 좋아요, 이건 가져가고 나중에 또 올 거죠?

translation.en: -I can. Yes. Thank you. -Okay, there you go.
[James] The people of Mayfield make Mayfield.
And each one of us will play a part in the rebuilding of this.
translation.ko: 재건을 위해 각자의 역할을 할 거예요

translation.en: -Thank you, Ma'am. -Thank you.
And the people that are here, that are gonna stay here,
that are gonna to rebuild,
that's Mayfield.
[Brett] Here's the thing. Mayfield is not unique.
translation.ko: 중요한 건 메이필드가 특별한 경우가 아니라는 거죠

translation.en: It's just the latest city to be hit by a tornado.
translation.ko: 가장 최근에 토네이도가 휩쓴 도시일 뿐이에요

translation.en: There will be more.
There are always more tornadoes.
And people like me, will be there to record the power of Mother Nature
when it strikes.
It makes you feel kind of vulnerable,
never knowing when that next tornado is going to come your way.
translation.ko: 다음 토네이도가 언제 당신을 덮칠지 모르니까요

translation.en: Subtitle translation by: Antoinette Smit
